deck: Humanity is the second game from Enhance Games after Tetris Effect.
description:
Enhance and Tha Ltd., which is a design studio in Tokyo, announced Humanity at Sony's "State of Play" in September 2019. The game will be playable in VR or without. The teams are aiming for a 2020 release.

Humanity has a unique look. The game focuses on crowds of people. Those crowds will impact gameplay in positive and negative ways.

Yugo Nakamura, from Tha Ltd., came up with the concept for the game. Tha Ltd. is famous for their work with Japanese brands like Uniqlo and Muji. They've also worked with Japanese musician Cornelius. Enhance came in to flesh out the game elements and publish the title for Nakamura and Tha Ltd.

“From the first early demo I saw, I couldn’t get Humanity out of my head,” said Enhance's Tetsuya Mizuguchi in a press release. “The whole look and feel of it—manipulating these teeming masses of people—was mesmerizing, especially in VR. I knew right away it could be something special, which is why I couldn’t be more excited to help a visionary like Yugo-san realize its full potential.”

“I’ve long admired the work of Mizuguchi-san and his team; it feels like the perfect fit to be working with the people who made games like Rez and Tetris Effect,” says Nakamura. “Everyone at Tha is working hard to make Humanity something that likewise engages all your senses—a fun, challenging game, but also something more meaningful than that. Rest assured we have lots more to show and talk about…"
name: Humanity

deck: Sequel to the award-winning and revolutionary virtual reality game.
description:
Overview

Yupitergrad 2: The Lost Station is a new installment of Yupitergrad, a VR platformer game about traversing the space station from the small, indie studio Gamedust.

The game starts when we drift into space with our AI companion, AIsha. After a time, we pick up a signal from a nearby space station. When we reach it, however, it seems abandoned - it's time to investigate its secret.

The game quickly introduces players to a new situation. We have at our disposal not only mobility equipment - iconic suction cup launchers but also weapons and conversational equipment. The world can be freely traversed, looking for new passages, puzzles, and fighting with rebellious machines. Yupitergrad 2: The Lost Station is a modern Metroidvania, for the first time, in VR.

System Requirements

PC

PC MinimumPC Recommended
  • Operating System: Windows 10/11 (64-bit)
  • Processor: Intel i5-4590 / AMD FX 8350
  • Memory: 8 GB
  • Graphics: Nvidia GTX 970 or equivalent
  • Storage: 1 GB
  • Operating System: Windows 10/11 (64-bit)
  • Processor: Intel Core i7 Skylake or equivalent
  • Memory: 16 GB
  • Graphics: Nvidia GTX 1060 or equivalent

External Links

  • Steam Storepage
  • Official Discord server
  • Official Twitter Profile
  • Official Instagram Profile
  • Official YouTube Channel
name: Yupitergrad 2: The Lost Station

deck: The sixth mainline entry in the legendary fighting game series.
description:
Overview

Street Fighter 6 is the sequel to Street Fighter V, developed and published by Capcom in 2023 for PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S.

SF6 returns to the "urban" themes prevalent in the Street Fighter III series, and Metro City (first seen in Final Fight) plays a key role in the story.

Playable Characters

The game's base starting roster is 18, consisting of 12 veterans and 5 newcomers.

Returning

  • Blanka
  • Cammy White
  • Chun-Li
  • Dee Jay
  • Dhalsim
  • Edmond Honda
  • Guile
  • Juri Han
  • Ken Masters
  • Luke Sullivan
  • Ryu
  • Zangief

New

  • Jamie, a drunken kung-fu fighter from Hong Kong who is associated with Lee, Yun, and Yang.
  • JP
  • Kimberly, an American ninja student of Guy (from Final Fight).
  • Lily
  • Manon
  • Marisa

Commentary

For the first time in series history, Street Fighter 6 has included play-by-play commentary from many of the Fighting Game Communtiy's top commentators.

English

  • James Chen
  • Jeremy Lopez
  • Tasty Steve
  • Thea Trinidad

Japanese

  • Aru
  • H.E.Demon Kakka
  • Kosuke Hiraiwa
name: Street Fighter 6

deck: The second mainline entry in the Dead Island franchise.
description:
Overview

Set a handful of years post-Dead Island: Riptide, the zombie infection has now spread into the American state of California. Four new characters, all of whom are immune to the infection, must now take up whatever weaponry they can find in order to survive the encroaching apocalypse.

Gameplay

Gameplay in Dead Island 2 is highly reminiscent of its predecessors, with it featuring the same brand of analogue-control melee combat for use against shambling hordes of zombies -- weapon crafting returns as well. What is new, however, is the inclusion of dual-wielding, which includes players being able to equip a ranged weapon in one hand and a melee weapon in the other. Players can also craft their unique weaponry anywhere in the world without the use of a workbench.

Cooperative play is once again available, only now has a capacity of eight, raised from the original Dead Island's four.

The world of Dead Island 2 is open-ended and there is no actual 'end' to the game. Instead, the world is said to continually introduce new missions within the world as players explore. Players will also come into contact with other players in the world at random as well, similar to games such as Destiny and Journey.

Development

Dead Island 2 was announced during E3, 2014 amidst Sony's conference. There was no gameplay shown, but instead a CG trailer. However unlike the original's own CG announcement trailer, Dead Island 2's depicted a much more comical and rambunctious tone. After the trailer had aired, there was much speculation over whether American actor and musician Jack Black was starring in it, due to VO from one of the characters bearing a resemblance. Jack Black himself later denied any involvement with the game during a Reddit 'Ask Me Anything' event.

A possible first for the industry, a cat--called Rick Furry in the game--underwent motion-capture for Dead Island 2. Many of the zombies' faces are modelled after developers working at YAGER.

On July 14th, Deep Silver announced that YAGER were to be no longer developing Dead Island 2. Timo Ullmann, the managing director at YAGER, stated that they and Deep Silver had a ''difference of vision'' towards the game, which lead to their departure.
name: Dead Island 2

deck: Arcade racing with a stylized artstyle.
description:
Overview

Sunrise GP mixes the sunny climate and the atmosphere of Grand Prix racing. There are a lot of references to games from the 90s, but with the standards of the current generation.

This is the first game of the Garage 5 team, which stands out with its atmosphere and content compared to a similar title of this (indie) scale. Players can try the Grand Prix mode, challenge modes, or even play split-screen mode for four players (which works very well on Nintendo Switch).

The game is designed for racing fans who want to combine driving with relaxation. Despite the strong connection with the “Grand Prix” term, the creators focus on a laid-back experience and the joy of driving a car.

External Links

  • Official Website
  • Official Discord Server
  • Official Twitter Profile
  • Official Facebook Fanpage
name: Sunrise GP

deck: An RPG with gacha elements where players take on the role of The Trailblazer, an artificially-created human with a relic called the "Stellaron" inside them, as they travel through the universe on a literal space-train.
description:
Overview

Honkai: Star Rail is a free-to-play, single-player, turn-based RPG with a gacha system for collecting characters and weapons. Developed and produced by the HoYoverse (miHoYo's overarching franchise) for PC and mobile platforms with an expected release date of April 26, 2023. The game is considered a sequel to the events of Honkai Impact 3rd, but is set in an alternate universe.

Gameplay

After progressing past the first part of the story, players can organize a team of up to four characters and are not required to have The Trailblazer in them, except for certain missions where the team composition is locked to require them. Each character has 5 different skills, 3 of which are actively used in combat, and another 2 that can passively effect the battle:

  • Basic Attack: A character performs their basic attack to deal damage to a single enemy, and the party gains a Skill Point (up to a maximum of 5)
  • Skill Attack: A more powerful attack that has properties unique to the character using them, ranging from an AoE attack, or buffing an ally. This attack requires one Skill Point from the party's shared pool to use.
  • Ultimate Attack: A different kind of skill attack, but used from a special meter unique to each character during combat that can only be charged when they attack, or are attacked by an enemy, or certain other effects gained from ally skills or Light Cones. Once the Ultimate meter is fully charged, the Ultimate can be launched at any time after the current attacker's turn, regardless of if they are friend or foe.
  • Talent: Each character's unique passive ability that allows them support themselves or their allies in combat.
  • Technique: A unique ability that can be used on the field before getting into combat. This can involve buffing your own team or performing a more powerful first strike on the enemy before entering combat. The player only has a maximum of 3 Technique Points, but can recharge them at certain points on the field.
name: Honkai: Star Rail

deck: A followup game to Road 96 which goes down a new route of gameplay.
description:
Overview

Road 96: Mile 0 is a prequel set before the events of the first Road 96 game. Unlike the first game which focused on narrative drama forged by procedural generation, the game instead focuses on a set storyline that is driven by narrative drama interspersed with musical rhythm game sections.

Gameplay

Like in Road 96, the game is played out from the first person perspective by exploring the environment and interacting with other characters that will change the story or overall narrative. Along the way, the player can also partake in various mini-games that might change the outcome of a narrative section or reward the player with a new skillset that will aid the player in any character interaction.

New to the gameplay are "Musical Rides", rhythm game sections that will allow players to better understand the main characters and flesh out the story.

Characters

The game follows two teenagers from previous Digixart games: Road 96 and Lost in Harmony. Zoe, from Road 96, is the daughter of a Petrian politician who lives in the privileged and luxurious community of White Sands, the capitol city of Petria. Kaito, a character adapted from Lost in Harmony, is a skateboarder who lives in the poorer part of White Sands having moved with his parents from the crime-ridden Colton City in hopes of living a better life.

Other characters from the previous game are also set to appear, such as news anchor Sonya Sanchez and taxi driver Jarod.
name: Road 96: Mile 0

deck: Don’t Byte Your Tongue
description:
About The Game

"Don't Byte Your Tongue" is a precision platformer that tests players' skills to the limit. With a simple premise of getting to the top, the gameplay is easy to learn but hard to master, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. However, as players progress through the game, they'll face increasingly difficult challenges that will require their full attention and skill to overcome.

The game features multiple modes that offer varying levels of difficulty and challenge, including the original KiloByte mode, which requires players to climb to the top and avoid falling back down. The MegaByte mode adds a timer and a danger zone that moves to the location of the last landing spot, making it even more challenging. The GigaByte mode takes it a step further, making players lose all progress if the timer reaches 0. And finally, the TeraByte mode is the hardest, giving players less time to move out of the danger zone and randomly inverting their launch controls.

In addition to the challenging gameplay, the game also features beautiful 8-bit retrowave art and addictive synthwave tracks that enhance the overall experience. There are a total of 8 levels, each adding a unique twist to the game, as well as secret collectibles hidden throughout the levels that players can bring to the top for their robot partner.

Players will also encounter NPCs that may bully them for not being good enough but can occasionally provide useful advice. And if players are looking for a real challenge, the game offers competitive cross-platform leaderboards that allow them to show off their skills and climb to the top of the global rankings.

Overall, "Don't Byte Your Tongue" is a high difficulty platformer that will test players' skills, make them rage, and keep them coming back for more. So players should try their best, not get too mad, and see if they have what it takes to make it to the top!

Development History

"Don't Byte Your Tongue" was started as a project amongst a group of students due to their love for rage games. The team aimed to create an addictive rage game with a goal of establishing a simple set of mechanics that would be easy to understand for any type of player but difficult to master as the game progresses. Rage games were mostly seen as unfair games that brought entertainment to only viewers and not the actual player. However, the team's goal for "Don't Byte Your Tongue" was to create a rage game that was fair but still retained the brutal punishments expected from a rage game. The game then transformed from a concept into a prototype back in January of 2022.

Since the summer of 2022, "Don't Byte Your Tongue" has been beta tested by their beta testers in their Discord community. The final version was completed in the first week of April after almost a year and three months of work. It was simply a passion project created by a group of undergraduates who did not want to study.
name: Don't Byte Your Tongue
